title: 112_s1243
content: The Act is known as the "AMERICA Works Act" and aims to establish industry-recognized credentials for job training programs. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 prioritizes programs offering industry-recognized credentials for training services. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 emphasizes the importance of programs leading to credentials in demand in the local area. The AMERICA Works Act emphasizes the importance of programs leading to industry-recognized credentials in demand, giving priority consideration to such programs. The AMERICA Works Act prioritizes programs that lead to industry-recognized credentials in demand, which can also serve as a basis for additional certificates or degrees. Local funds under the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 are required to describe career and technical education activities supporting the attainment of industry-recognized credentials. The AMERICA Works Act emphasizes industry-recognized credentials in demand for training programs. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 requires activities supporting the attainment of such credentials. The Trade Act of 1974 also includes provisions for training programs leading to industry-recognized credentials. The Secretary prioritizes training programs leading to credentials in demand in the local area, as specified in the AMERICA Works Act. The Secretary prioritizes training programs leading to credentials in demand in the local area, as specified in the AMERICA Works Act. SEC. 3. SKILL CREDENTIAL REGISTRY. The term "covered provision" includes specific sections from various acts. "Industry-recognized" refers to credentials accepted by companies in the industry and endorsed by a recognized trade association. The term "nationally portable" refers to credentials accepted across multiple states in the industry sector. The Secretary of Labor is required to create a registry of skill credentials within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must list credentials in a registry if they are required by federal or state law for an occupation, enabling priority under a covered provision. The Secretary will list credentials in a registry if they are required by law for an occupation, giving priority under a covered provision. The registry will also include credentials from the Manufacturing Institute-Endorsed Manufacturing Skills Certification System and industry-recognized, nationally portable credentials consistent with industry competency models. Entities are not required to select programs with credentials listed in the registry. The Act and its amendments will become effective 120 days after enactment.
